content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: There are already some probability themed puzzles, but this one seems different enough.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ok for me!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Cards usually don't have a quantity but either a rank value or (face) number - quantity sounds odd, atleast to me.

Goal
* Please add "a" before "deck".

* In the examples of invalid sets, we currently have
  • 1st example: 3 invalid feature sets
  • 2nd example: 1 invalid feature set
  • 3rd example: 1 invalid feature set
  
  Consider modifying either the 2nd or 3rd example so that it includes 2 or 4 invalid feature sets instead of just 1.

Goal / Input
* Please consistently use either "property"/"properties" or "feature"/"features".

Constraints
* Please remove the second constraint.

Stub generator
* Line 6: Please change as follows:
loop n read quantity:int shading:word(10) color:word(10) shape:word(10)

Cases
* Please revise the following validators slightly so that they still cover the same scenario as their corresponding tests while expecting different outputs:
  • A simple start (Validator 1)
  • A few more cards (Validator 2)

* Please add a new pair of cases where the expected output is 0.0000.

Thanks.

P.S. For my own reference only, a clash on the same game: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/76014e291e737a54b13b6f71d063867841e36

Thank you for your feedback! I believe I have made most of the suggested edits, although I have some follow-up questions on the test cases.

Tests/Validators 1 & 2 both test probabilities without overlap (there aren't two possible sets you could form with the same card). Therefore, the same n will necessarily result in the same probability.

I have changed test 2 to have n = 6 instead of 5, but I am unsure about test/validator 1. I feel like even though it isn't an edge case, it makes sense to include the minimum n as both a test and validator. However, this does mean they will have the same answer regardless of what the two cards are. So I'm not sure what is best here.

Also, there is always at least one card which completes the set as long as you have n <= 2, so the expected output cannot be 0, although I could change the constraints if you think that would make more sense.

I suppose this makes more sense visually (in the real game there aren't any printed numbers, just that number of shapes). However I can see how quantity could be confusing so I have changed this to "number".

Could you please edit your comment so that we can read it?

Also, are you copying comments from other people again?

Thanks. I appreciate your quick reply and edits.

I understand your point about the probability never being 0 in the current setup, and that makes perfect sense; no need to change the constraints and force an impossible case there.

Regarding the tests and validators: if you feel that n = 5 is an important edge case worth keeping, please do restore the original validator. In that case, though, please add additional pairs of cases so that we end up with fewer validators expecting the same output as their corresponding tests. At the moment, 3 out of 6 share the same output, so reducing that to less than half would be better.

Thanks again.

In case you missed my previous comment: do you think you'll restore the original Validator 2, and add a few more pairs of cases so that less than half of the validators expect the same output as their corresponding tests?

I do not plan on restoring the original validator #2 since it was not a specific edge case of n = 5, but rather a specific type of case with no overlap, which the new validator still fulfills.

I have also now added new cases ("Lots of cards" and "Almost guaranteed") which have differing answers. Now the first one and last two share answers (all edge cases) while the other 5 have unique answers.
All right, looks good to me. Thank you.
